passages.text: **Maintain Rating: BUY | PO: 71.80 HKD | Price: 59.35 HKD**

We trim our 2025/26E EPS 2%/3% post Shenzhou's mixed result (see our first-take note), as we believe GP margin miss could slightly outweigh topline beat. Accordingly,we lower PO 2% to HK$71.8. We maintain our Buy rating for its consistent share gains that can support better-than-peers orderbook visibility, its 30% underperformance vs.HSI Index YTD, undemanding valuation (12.9x 2025 P/E, vs. an average of mid- to high-teens P/E for leading China consumer names), and c.5% dividend yield.

Shenzhou's sales growth with key clients significantly outpaced their company-wide growth in 1H25 (Nike/aldidas/Uniqlo/Puma +6%/+28%/+27%/+15%). Its superior supply chain (fast lead time, high production quality, lower cost and strong fabric innovation) supports share gains. For example, Shenzhou's newly launched soccer apparel for adidas has been a huge success, and we expect the series to contribute >30% of its adidas orders in the coming 12 months. Admittedly, we believe its topline strength in 1H25 was partly due to order frontloading (the US +36%/Nike +6% in 1H25). Therefore,Nike's future turnaround pace will likely be key to Shenzhou's share price, in our view.

Most incoming questions post results were about Shenzhou's GPM miss. We expect its 2H25 GPM to be only marginally better than 1H25 (27.1%), but still below 2024 (28.1%) and pre-COVID level (30%+). Its sales mix shift back to sportswear is positive, but we are concerned with tariffs and China. Various sources suggest Vietnam's new tariff with the US is old tariff+20%, 10% higher than the tariff pause period in 2Q25. We expect Shenzhou to share some tariffs with certain client. In addition, China's sales were -2% in 1H25, and a likely sub-optimal capacity utilization in China may also weigh on margins.Again, Nike's recovery pace will be a swing factor to Shenzhou's 12-month margin outlook, as historically Nike's orders enjoy better margins than others.

Shenzhou is the world's largest vertically integrated knitwear manufacturer. The firm is the largest apparel supplier to Nike, Adidas, Puma and Uniqlo, which we estimate accounts for mid- teens % of their respective market shares.

We rate Shenzhou a Buy, given its (1) solid earnings outlook with good visibility, (2) industry- high OP/ NPM/earnings CAGR, and (3) consistent share gain driven by R&D strength, vertical integration, superior production quality, automation and quick lead time. We believe Shenzhou deserves a valuation premium over other original equipment manufacturer (OEM) peers and see rating potential on its defensive, visible growth profile.
\* For full definitions of iQmethod™ measures, see page 8.

Post our earnings revision, we lower PO 2% to HK$71.8, based on a 50/50 blend of P/E and DCF. Our P/E value (HK$70.6) is based on 15x 2025E P/E (the same as before). Our DCF value (HK$73) assume 11.5% WACC, 1x beta and 2.5% terminal growth (the same as before).

We value Shenzhou at HK\$71.8 based on a 50/50 blend of DCF (HK\$73, assuming 11.5% WACC, 1x beta and a 2.5% terminal growth rate) and P/E (HK\$70.6, based on 15x 2025E P/E). Our target P/E of 15x is 20% below the 10-year average given the slower EPS growth than the historical average and uncertainty related to US/China trade tensions.

Upside risks to our price objective are (1) better-than- expected sales and margins, (2) additional revenue from new customers, (3) a sharp fall in raw material prices, (4) faster than expected capacity expansion. (5) FX is better than expected. (6) Better than expected US/China trade tensions.

Downside risks to our price objective are (1) weaker- than expected sales/margins due to macro & COVID uncertainty, (2) slower than expected capacity expansion, (3) a sharp RMB/USD appreciation, and (4) unfavorable China/US trade policy change. (5) FX is worse than expected. (6) Worse than expected US/China trade tensions.
